articles.title: JSR is Not Another Package Manager
articles.description: When Ryan created Node, JavaScript had no packages or standard module system. npm and CommonJS took off, and tools like Yarn or pnpm extended npm in certain areas, but in today's ES modules era, it’s time for a transformation. JSR is not merely a new npm, but a shift in how packages are distributed, tailored for the modern era.
articles.author: Ryan Dahl

articles.title: Node.js v22 (Current) Released
articles.description: The newest, cutting edge, major version of Node lands with some key enhancements. v22 becomes the new ‘current’ release (becoming active LTS in October). It adds support for require-ing ESM, gets a built-in WebSocket client, upgrades to V8 12.4, and includes a task runner (e.g. node --run task_name). This blog post takes a closer look.
articles.author: Rafael Gonzaga

articles.title: pnpm 9.0: The Efficiency-Focused Package Manager
articles.description: pnpm has long been a fantastic option for folks looking to save disk space and CPU cycles (or for its great monorepo support) while maintaining most of what makes npm great. v9.0 drops Node 16 and 17 compatibility, honors the packageManager field in package.json, makes some default config changes, and adopts Lockfile v9.
articles.author: pnpm

articles.title: A Tale of Migrating a Project to Bun
articles.description: Eric, an engineer at Render, walks through the steps of how he migrated his Sveld project to Bun (replacing Yarn and Vitest in the process), including some minor gotchas he encountered, and what the speed gains were.
articles.author: Eric Liu

articles.title: The Frontend Developer/Engineer Handbook 2024
articles.description: A guide to the current webdev landscape, covering how to get up to speed on topics like editors, CSS, UX, UI, the command line, tools and frameworks, perf, accessibility, etc.
articles.author: Cody Lindley

articles.title: HTML Attributes vs DOM Properties
articles.description: They’re different, but often coupled. Jake outlines the the difference, and why it matters.
articles.author: Jake Archibald

articles.title: ▶  A Node.js Streams Masterclass
articles.description: An hour-long odyssey with the creator of Fastify (and Node.js TSC member) into the world of streams. A stream is like an array over time.. we learn, before going into live coding and demos.
articles.author: Matteo Collina

articles.title: 📊 Unovis: A Modular Data Visualization Framework
articles.description: Works with React, Angular, Svelte, Vue or plain old JS/TS. Handles all sorts of things from Sankey diagrams to maps, graphs, chord diagrams, and traditional line/area charts. The v1.4 release adds support for annotating visualizations in a flexible way. There’s a gallery of examples (with code) if you want to dig in.
articles.author: F5, Inc.

articles.title: ReScript 11.1 Released with Improved JSX Support
articles.description: ReScript is an OCaml-inspired, typed language that compiles to JavaScript and has a JSX transform built into the language. JSX support was previously solely for React use cases, but now works with Vue, Preact, and other approaches too.
articles.author: The ReScript Project

articles.title: typed-xlsx: Feature-Rich Type-Safe Excel Reporting
articles.description: Define a strongly typed spreadsheet schema, then populate and work with the sheets directly from JS/TS, such as for generating reports for users – example code. Wraps around SheetJS. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Cyprien Thao

articles.title: Devalue 5.0: Like JSON.stringify, But..
articles.description: “Gets the job done when JSON.stringify can’t.” Namely, it can handle cyclical and repeated references, regular expressions, Map and Set, custom types, and more.
articles.author: Rich Harris

articles.title: imask.js 7.6.0: A Vanilla JavaScript Input Mask
articles.description: Prevent users from entering invalid values. Has plugins for Vue, Angular, React, Svelte, and Solid, as needed.
articles.author: imaskjs

articles.title: browser-or-node 3.0: Figure Out Where Your Code is Running
articles.description: Provides a simple way to tell if your code is currently running in a browser, in Node, in a Web Worker, or in Deno. Works with both ESM and CJS imports.
articles.author: Dinesh Pandiyan

articles.description: 🙈 Yesterday was JS Naked Day, a day to go entirely without JavaScript. Sadly we missed it.. 😏
🇫🇷 dotJS 2024 is a JavaScript conference taking place in Paris, France on June 27. The speaker roster so far is pretty compelling.
rcompat is an interesting JS interoperability and runtime compatibility layer for servers, so you can avoid the differences between Node, Deno and Bun.
React Native 0.74
Electron 30.0 – Now with Chromium 124, V8 12.4, and Node.js 20.11.1.
Hexo 7.2 – Static site generator for blogging.
Ember 5.8, Ionic 8, SWC 1.5, Knip 5.10.0

articles.title: Help Invent CSS Grid Level 3, Aka “Masonry” Layout
articles.description: Masonry style layouts (above) see content laid out like a brick/stone wall. It’s a popular pattern, but one that rapidly becomes difficult to get just right. Real-world feedback is now being sought from devs and designers on how CSS should handle such layouts. This article runs through the current proposal, the debate at the heart of things, and how to share your thoughts.
articles.author: Jen Simmons (WebKit)

articles.title: The Frontend Developer/Engineer Handbook 2024
articles.description: An in-depth, detailed, and free guide to the current web development landscape. It's a superb resource (by way of Frontend Masters) for getting up to speed on everything from code editors, CSS, UX, UI, the command line, popular tools and frameworks, performance, accessibility, testing, AI, and much more. One to bookmark/share.
articles.author: Cody Lindley

articles.title: Upgrading jQuery: Working Towards a Healthy Web
articles.description: Yes, jQuery is still pretty much everywhere, so considering its staying power here’s what work is being done to ensure jQuery users stay up to date. This online tool can tell you if the version you’re running is out of date.
articles.author: Timmy Willison (jQuery)

articles.title: ▶  A Conversation with Una Kravets: The Rapid Evolution of CSS
articles.description: An interview with Una, the Web UI DevRel lead at Google, discussing web development, the progression of CSS over the years, and how layout/style ideas end up a reality.
articles.author: Kevin Powell

articles.title: Detect JavaScript Support in CSS
articles.description: A way to provide alternative CSS rules depending on whether or not JavaScript is available in the user’s browser. It can also help reduce flashes of unstyled content or undesirable layout shifts. There are a few gotchas to be aware of though.
articles.author: Ryan Mulligan

articles.title: HTML Attributes vs. DOM Properties
articles.description: They’re completely different, but often coupled. Jake outlines the the difference, and why it matters.
articles.author: Jake Archibald

articles.title: Don’t Use the maxlength Attribute to Stop Users From Exceeding the Limit
articles.description: “the maxlength attribute doesn’t improve UX, it degrades it”.
articles.author: Adam Silver

articles.title: The F-Shape Pattern and How Users Read
articles.description: When users consume your content they will be scrolling, scanning, and skipping around your page. Here’s what you need to know about typical reading behavior and design strategies you can consider to prevent potentially unwanted scanning patterns.
articles.author: Vitaly Friedman

articles.title: Long Alt
articles.description: Keep your image alternative text brief, devoid of special characters, empty of URLs, and ideally in one language.
articles.author: Adrian Roselli

articles.title: Quill 2.0: A Powerful Rich Text Editor for the Web
articles.description: This is a major release for the popular open-source WYSIWYG editor, and represents a significant modernization of things. Here's the announcement post outlining what's new in 2.0 post, and the repo too. Not tried it before? There’s a playground.
articles.author: Slab Inc.

articles.title: Wedges: A Collection of UI Components for React
articles.description: A well thought out, aesthetically pleasing set of UI and Tailwind CSS based components. You can also download a Figma file of them to use when mocking up layouts. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Lemon Squeezy

articles.title: The Ultimate CSS Shapes Collection
articles.description: Single-element implementation. Lots to choose from, including some rather novel options. One click to copy the code!
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: MarkdownDown: Convert Any Web Page to Clean Markdown with Images Downloaded
articles.description: Just enter a URL and choose from optional settings to remove non-content elements, link vs. download for the images, and apply further instructions to customize the code via GPT-3.5.
articles.author: Asad Memon

articles.title: Mastodon Embed Timeline Widget
articles.description: Easily embed a Mastodon timeline on your site. No dependencies, no trackers, cross-browser, WCAG compliant and fully responsive. Demo here.
articles.author: i.j

articles.title: consent-banner-js: A Zero-Dependency, Lightweight Cookie Banner
articles.description: Comes in at just ~3KB, consent platform agnostic – pretty straightforward.
